Fields.DialogueText: Captain? Excuse me, Captain?
Henley, look at the clipboard in my hand. Do you see how fast I'm walking? I've got a lot on my plate right now. What do you need?
Actually, Captain, that's exactly what I've come here to talk about!
A plan of action in case of the possibility of sorties by Morgana forces from the south?
No, Captain. Actually, I wanted to discuss dinner.
Dinner?
Oh, come on! You said that thing about a plate, remember?

Fields.MenuText: The safety of this ship is at stake right now. I don't have time for banter.
All right, Henley, I suppose you're right. It was a decent joke.
Oh, ha! You're a miracle worker, Henley, causing a ship captain at war to smile like that.

Fields.DialogueText: Right of course, Captain. I should have known.
Decent? Captain, you know that joke was good.
Miracle worker!? I've never been called that before, Captain…Oh, you're making my face hotter than a red pepper.
Listen, Henley, I'd love to hear you out, but I've got a crew to look out for at the moment.
Looks like you may have more than that to deal with, Captain.
Morganas! You know what to do, Henley.
Slice and dice!
@BATTLE
Cowards seem to have grown tired of battle already. Good work, Henley.
Thanks Captain, but it was hardly work. Felt like the only thing I worked on was my appetite. Oh, speaking of! About that dinner, Captain?
Henley, I barely have time to make it to the mess hall, and now you're constantly badgering me about some complicated dinner plan?
Come on, Captain. You can't say you're not the least bit intrigued? A mysterious dinner plan with a young lady?

Fields.MenuText: Just what are you getting at, Henley?
Perhaps the thought does carry a breeze through my sails…
Please, Henley, thoughts of young women are the most dangerous weapons to a sailor at war.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Captain! Why so serious and glum? I'm just trying to have a little fun!
Captain! I'm only kidding…
Do you speak from personal experience, Captain?
Captain! Command is on the radio, and they're asking for you. It's urgent, they say.
Sorry, Henley, but I'll just have to wait to hear your proposition another time. Let's hope this urgent news is good, whatever it is.
Uh, Captain… You should wait to go to the radio room. Look to port.
Morganas… Positions, everyone!
@BATTLE
Hey, Captain! Oh, uh. Maybe I should just come back. Yeah, I left something in the galley.
Wait! Henley. What is it?
Um… Well, I was going to remind you about that dinner plan I talked about before, but then I saw the look on your… I mean, uh… What did Command say?
The odds are certainly stacked against us. Repeated sightings of multiple Morgana ships approaching from the south.
Nope, certainly doesn't sound good, does it, Captain? Have you thought of a plan yet?
Apparently, I've actually been too busy entertaining certain members of the crew.
Really? That's impossible. I think I'm the person you talk to the most.
Never mind, Henley.
Wait, I've got a great idea!

Fields.MenuText: Let's hear it. I'm putting my faith into you.
Sorry, but I really need to alert other members of the crew. We need to be ready for anything.
Another time, Henley. Sorry, but we need to make preparations.

Fields.DialogueText: You're talking to a William and Mary girl here, Captain. You can count on me!
Well maybe my idea would have helped us prepare! But now you'll never know.
I'm beginning to hear you say that phrase more and more.
*ALARM*
Looks like it'll just have to wait, Henley. We've got some enemies riding our coattails.
Captain, how can you expect us to work together when you don't even want to listen to me?
Henley! Now is not the time. I order you to fight.
Fine, Captain! You're right. But promise me that if we survive this, you'll listen to what I have to say.
You're a bold lady, Henley.
Bold? A miracle worker?
Fine! Yes. Any more dallying and it'll be a miracle if we survive.
@BATTLE
All right, Captain. Who knows when I'll get another opportunity to say this, so I'm just going to spit it out.
Doesn't really sound like I have a choice in the matter.
You taught me how to cook delicious spaghetti, but I'm worried I'll forget how. The first time was so good, but how do I know the next time will be just as good?
What exactly are we talking about here, Henley?
I need you to walk me through the recipe one more time. Please, Captain, I need practice.
And this benefits our war efforts how?
That's just it, Captain. We can talk all about the Morganas from the south while we're cooking! Think about it. It's a great opportunity to discuss strategy.
Discuss strategy? Henley, you and I both know that your only strategy seems to be a stern-first blitz at the enemy.
I'm not just some one-trick pony, Captain. What do you say? Help me with the recipe again?

Fields.MenuText: Henley, I think we both know that now is not the time. I'm sorry. Perhaps when we're safer, or when things are more certain.
All right, Henley. If you agree to focus on strategizing our survival, I'll walk you through the recipe again. Maybe we'll even add extra spice this time.
Sorry, Henley, but my focus is completely absorbed in the war.

Fields.DialogueText: I think I understand. You don't want to give up your chef's secrets! Maybe you don't know what you're missing out on, Captain.
Some extra spices, huh? Are you sure you can handle that?
You'll come around, Captain. Everyone gets hungry sometime.
Oh, Henley… Listen, I'm sorry. Wait.
Captain?
I can't have you looking like that if Morganas press us. I'll walk you through the recipe again.
Captain! You're sweeter than maple syrup, or cherrry pie… or cake.
*ALARM*
Battle beckons. Prepare to fire!
@BATTLE
Looks like that was the last of them. Fierce work, Henley. Now let's break to the galley. Who knows how long we've got until Morganas find us again.
Now that's a plan of action I fully support, Captain!
Unless... Unless you're sneaking food when I'm not looking? Captain... you wouldn't do that, would you?
All right, Henley. You've got the sauce simmering, right?
Sauce is simmering!
And the water is almost boiling?
Just starting to bubble.
Remember the next step?
Throw the noodles in the water?
Good work, Henley. Listen, I need to check on deck operations. Think you can handle yourself?
Wait, Captain! We're almost done here. Don't leave me yet. I don't want to mess something up at the very end!

Fields.MenuText: Then don't mess up, Henley.
Come on, Henley. You're one tough girl. You can do this. I believe in you.
What's the problem, Henley? I'm leaving you alone in a room full of food. Isn't this pretty much everything you've always wanted?

Fields.DialogueText: Gee, Captain, I hadn't thought of it that way.
You really think so? You're making my cheeks look like this marinara sauce, Captain. I guess if you say so…
Well, sure, when you put it that way, Captain! But truth be told, there are other things I want.
You're going to do fine, Henley. Now get those pasta noodles in the water. I'm off to the deck, but I'll be back.
Looks like we're both headed up.
Let's show these Morganas what we're capable of!
@BATTLE
Seems we live to fight another day, Henley. Listen, I've got some things to take care of. Don't forget about the stove.
Oh, drat, my spaghetti!
*ALARM*
Captain! I'm so glad I've found you.
Henley, I always do deck checks at around this time. You know exactly where to find me.
Right, well, listen - there is something urgent going on in the galley. Come quick!
Don't tell me you burned it down.
There's no time for discussion, Captain.
Are you trying to pull one over on me, Henley?
Captain! You don't trust me?

Fields.MenuText: Of course I trust you! You're the spirit of the very ship I captain.
Something tells me you're up to mischief.
The question, Henley, is should I trust you?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't play dumb with me, Captain. You know that's not what I meant!
Me? Mischief? Captain, I ought to be offended. I'm a good girl… I am!
I guess that's just a risk you're going to have to decide for yourself, Captain.
How about when I do an expression like… this! You don't trust this sweet face?
Damn it, Henley! That right there tells me that you're not being serious. Joking about a naval emergency is no light offense, sailor.
Captain! Are you going to scold me?
*BOOM*
Looks like the Morganas saved you this time. Get ready for battle, Henley.
@BATTLE
Captain, hold on!
I'm trying, but you're really rocking this time, Henley.
Ah-ha! Got you. Errr! Come on, Captain. I'm trying to pull you up, and you're not helping at all.
Henley… You saved me from nearly going into the water there.
Don't mention it, Captain. At least the Morganas are gone! Now will you come to the galley with me?
How can I refuse?
I finally agree to follow you to the galley, and then you leave me to wait an eternity!
I'm sorry, Captain! But look, I've returned. Now's the time. It's urgent, remember?
Perhaps you're oblivious to the amount of effort that goes into running a ship during war.
Nobody knows it better than the ship herself! Now follow me, okay?

Fields.MenuText: This has taken up too much time already.
You saved my life, Henley. I'm right behind you!
We are going to the galley, right?

Fields.DialogueText: It hasn't taken up enough! You've been making dead sure of that.
Captain, would you forget about that already? Saddle up!
Just what are you trying to say, Captain?
Fine, you've reeled me in. Let's go. Hopefully nothing happens in my absence.
Oh, Captain. It's not like you're going very far. Just a couple steps, and a staircase, and a big heavy door, and… here!
Henley… This is… This is amazing.
You really think so!?
Captain! Morganas off the port bow! It's urgent.
Of course… Prepare to fire!
@BATTLE
Do you want to explain yourself, Henley?
Captain, what do you mean?
In all my time aboard this ship, I've never seen this galley look so clean. There's flowers on the table… Where did you even get flowers?
Just lying around in storage! They're fake, and dusty… but they add an irresistible kind of flair, don't they?
Candles…
Tell me what else you like about what's in this room.
Dark chocolate rations on the table…
Look, I even finished making the spaghetti.
Henley, that looks and smells incredible.
I had a good teacher. Care for a glass of red wine?

Fields.MenuText: I'd love something to whet my appetite.
I'd prefer a whiskey.

Fields.DialogueText: Then allow me, Captain!
Wine's the only thing we've got. I bet you want a lot of things you can't have, Captain.
*ALARM*
Morganas! I should have spotted them already. You can explain all of this later, Henley.
But I thought it was obvious...
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: White wouldn't pair better?

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Now who's the teacher? Red with marinara, and don't you forget it.
Captain! Well, are you?
Am I what?
Are you upset with me?
Right, of course. Sorry, it's so hard to hear you over the roar of the surf.
Answer the question, Captain!
I don't think upset is the right word, Henley. Confused. Confused is much more appropriate.
Confused? Over the dinner I set out?
Well the whole thing did come off rather... how should I say this, Henley?
Rather what?
Like a date, Henley! The whole thing seemed like a date.
Captain, how dare you! I was simply trying to make the meal look appealing. Besides, does the thought of a dinner date with me disturb you?

Fields.MenuText: It's just not what I expected, Henley. Never mind how I feel about the whole thing.
Henley, you and I both know that my position as captain of this ship keeps me from engaging in…romantic activities.
Disturb me? Henley, it's quite the opposite. I'd be honored for a dinner date with a girl who can handle herself in the galley and the battlefield.

Fields.DialogueText: But that's the most interesting part, Captain! Not that I am… interested, you know.
Can't handle a tough gal? Don't worry, Captain. I was only kidding anyway.
Captain! Your words are sweeter than fresh apple pie. Too bad we're only speculating.
So your intention wasn't…romantic in nature?
Captain, you're my cooking professor. I only wanted to show you how my skills have progressed.
Consider yourself a top student, then. Outstanding presentation, Henley. Perhaps next time you can tone down the wine and chocolate.
Captain! Morgana ships spotted portside.
Sound the alarm! Now let's see that attention to detail put into battle, Henley.
@BATTLE
Another successful battle, Henley. Good work, kid.
Kid, huh? That's a new one. Captain, you're not going to let my meal go to waste, are you? After I worked so hard…
I think we both deserve a good meal after that fight, Henley. Lead the way.
Henley! The garlic, the spice, the flavor… This is incredible!
Grazie, Captain! How about that glass of wine, now?
Molto bene, Henley, but I've got a job to do, and being intoxicated isn't going to help my efforts.
Of course. I really can be so forgetful sometimes…
If I said I weren't hesitant to believe you, I'd be lying.
I'm an honest girl, Captain! I swear.
I guess your word is all I have to go on.
Is that not good enough?
It'll have to be. Mm! That was a delicious meal, Henley. Bravo! Now, excuse me - I have some outstanding matters to attend to.
Leaving already, Captain? But you haven't even tried the dessert yet. Won't you stay for some chocolate?

Fields.MenuText: I guess a little bit of after-dinner sugar wouldn't put me too far behind schedule.
I've stayed down here for too long already, Henley. Sorry, but I must return to my duties.
Why do I get the feeling you're still stealthily peddling some ulterior motive?

Fields.DialogueText: Got a sweet tooth, Captain? Might get you that extra burst of energy you need.
All right, Captain, but you have no idea what is it you're missing out on!
Me? Captain! Can't I just enjoy company of a... dear friend during dinner?
*ALARM*
Looks like dessert is just going to have to wait, Henley. We've got Morganas to deal with.
They never seem to give up, do they, Captain?
More reason for us to fight harder. Prepare yourself, Henley.
@BATTLE
We live to fight again, Captain! So, how about that after-battle dessert?
Captain! Command is on the radio. They want to talk to you.
If it's not one thing...
Captain, I don't mean to sound rude, but you look a lot better when you smile.
A jarring and jaded compliment indeed, Henley. Now is not the time for such things, though. There's some heavy news coming down the pipeline.
And by the set of your jaw, I'm going to guess it's bad news.
You know, Henley, if sailing and cooking don't work out, you may just have a future as a detective.
You really think so? Detective Henley… Hmm, that does have a nice ring to it!
Put a pin in it. We're still at war here, and word is that southern fleet of Morganas is gaining on us.
You always sound so stressed when I talk to you, Captain. They say stress will shorten your life, you know?
Apparently they have never been on a destroyer in the middle of the ocean during war, fighting mysterious alien ghost ships!
Did you ever think that maybe you would work better... if you were more relaxed? That's how I feel after a delicious meal, at least.
That doesn't come as a surprise.
Maybe you just need a little help. I wonder if a massage might not loosen you up.
A what?
You look like you need a little massage! You don't want me to rub your shoulders for a little while?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe? But now is not the time. We are facing a serious threat, and we need to prepare.
Perhaps I could use a tension reliever. What the hell. Go at it, Henley!
Maybe I spoke to soon about the detective thing, because apparently you're not getting the hint.

Fields.DialogueText: Muscle fatigue and ache is a serious threat, Captain.
Captain! That's not the answer I expected. Oh no, you really are tense!
The hint? And what exactly are you talking about, Captain?
Damn… Look out the window, Henley. You see those shapes out there?
Captain, maybe those knotted muscles of yours have extended all the way to your brain.
Steer clear of that and look closer.
Oh, wait… Yep, those are definitely Morganas.
@BATTLE
Looks like they've turned and run already, Henley. Admirable work, but I'm afraid we're not done yet. There are still plenty of preparations to make.
I have to admit that a good fight can loosen me right up. It's the paperwork that gets a girl tense.
Captain? Captain?
Hey! Captain!
Henley! Can you really not tell that I'm taking inventory? Ah, and now I've lost count already. Great.
Relax, Captain. I just wanted to show you my latest outfit! I sewed this skirt back to health. How does it look, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: It looks good, Henley, but it's the least of my worries right now.
This is a naval cruiser, Henley. Not a model runway.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the point! If I couldn't appreciate the little things in life, I might as well have not even awakened.
I can't help it, Captain! I heard one of the British cruisers was designing new uniforms and the sewing bug chomped me but good.
Look Henley, don't take this the wrong way, but we really do have things to worry about. Several ally ships have already been reported missing or sunk just south of here.
Yesterday's news, Captain! We're working on it.
You might not take this seriously, Henley, but the rest of the crew can thank God that I do!
You're more stubborn than a stuck peanut butter lid! Did you ever think that maybe you can be serious without being a stick in the mud?
Oh yeah, well... you have a mustard stain on your shirt!
Captain… Am I interrupting anything?
What is it, Officer?
We've spotted some ships that look a bit like Morganas. They're fast approaching from the north.
This could be trouble. Sound the alarm!
First the south, then the north. They're never where we expect them to be.
You know what doesn't move around unexpectedly? This wonderful skirt I-
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Health indeed. I can't even tell it was sick.

Fields.DialogueText: Any sailor worth their salt knows how to repair their uniform!
Can it, Henley.
Henley! Taking another sandwich respite, I see.
Mmm… Long overdue, Captain. A sweet officer downstairs was gentlemanly enough to make it for me. He even cut the crusts off the way I like.
Henley, I don't mind the occasional break from duty. You do an exceptional job, and well, we all need to eat. But I can't have you distracting the other officers too.
Distracting the other officers? Huh, you're jealous! Are you jealous, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Jealous? Are you kidding me? There's finally another person you can bother to make you food.
No way, Henley. Please, I've got nothing to be jealous about. Nope, I don't care in the slightest.
And what if I was a little jealous, Henley? Would you hold it against me?

Fields.DialogueText: Hey! Belles have feelings, too. I thought you enjoyed cooking for me.
I see, Captain. Well I guess I'll just continue to enlist that kind-hearted officer for my future galley dealings.
You can be so funny sometimes, Captain. Just what are you referring to?
Look here, Henley, the threat from the south only grows closer. It could get ugly and we need to be ready for that.
I am preparing, Captain. Finish lunch, step one.
You're truly nothing short of dainty. The time to be serious is now, Henley. I've got a list of tasks we need to take care of, starting with…
*ALARM*
That fleet of Morganas coming at us.
@BATTLE
Seems we're finally safe again, for now.
Victory meal? What do you say, Captain?
No time, Henley. I'm afraid those ships are likely to be the first signs of something more menacing. It's time to break into that task list.
Roger dodger...
All right, task number one. We need a complete overhaul of all the safety equipment available on board.
What? Captain!
Life vests, inflatable dinghies, buoys…
Captain, this is an outrage.
Are you questioning my command, Henley?
Captain, you should know by now that I'm a faithful woman, but this is grunt work.
It's all hands on deck right now, Henley, and this is where we need you.
Wait… Are you trying to get rid of me, Captain? The safety equipment was just checked recently.
And we're facing another big potential battle. Orders are orders, Henley.
You just want to give me some menial task to get away from me, is that it? You just want me to leave you alone, huh?

Fields.MenuText: My sole objective here is ensuring the safety of my crew.
Do you feel like you've been interrupting me a lot? Like incessantly, maybe?
You hit the nail on the head, Henley. I need to think of a strategy here, and I'll never get anything done with you around.

Fields.DialogueText: You're a better multitasker than you give yourself credit for.
I didn't think so. I thought you enjoyed my company.
Are you saying I distract you, Captain? Is that because you find my company charming? Because you can't take your eyes off me?
To be one hundred percent honest, Henley, you have been spending a lot of time trying to get my attention.
I know what this is. You're trying to say I'm being overbearing.
Well… You have been acting a little strange recently.
Well, why don't you say how you really feel, Captain?
Captain!
Gah! How many people are vying for my attention?
Two, Captain.
That was a rhetorical question, Officer. Now what is it... what's the trouble?
*BOOM*
I see. Prepare to do what you do best, Henley.
Captain, I thought you'd never ask!
@BATTLE
Captain, we're all up to code, every single buoy and inflatable dinghy. Here's the record papers to prove it.
Henley, I'm speechless. This was no minor obligation, and you finished in record time. Did you cut some corners?
Negative, Captain. The only corners I cut are on my sandwiches.
Well, I wish I the rest of the crew was motivated like you.
Actually, I owe it all to you, Captain.
Is that so? So that means I really motivated you, huh? Thanks, Henley.
You sure did. Ever since you called me overbearing, I've had a burning question to ask you.

Fields.MenuText: Do you hear that? I thought I might have heard the alarm malfunction. I should go check on that.
I feel like I'm under siege here, Henley. But okay, fire away.
Quit putting words in my mouth, Henley. You're the one who suggested it.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh no, Captain! You're not pulling one over on me. Not this time!
Admirable, Captain. Only a strong person can talk face to face with a Belle when she's upset.
That's what you described, Captain. You led me straight there!
Well, fine then, Henley. You did an exemplary job with the task I assigned you. Ask your question.
You said I've been acting strange recently. What are you talking about, Captain? What do you mean?
Damn! Henley, portside. Looks like a couple of Morgana ships.
Nice try, Captain, but there's no escaping me this time.
You really think I orchestrated a bogus alarm to escape you?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Well, I wasn't going to suggest it. Am I overbearing or are you paranoid?
Could be a little of both.
I don't mean to be rude, Captain, but when are you going to answer me?
Henley, did you forget that safety and effort are our first priority?
You remind me a little of my ex-friend Shirley Averson.
The one you have a grudge against? Henley, I've got no time for schoolgirl dramatics. Who knows when those Morganas will return?
Captain!
All right, Henley, I'll tell you, but you have to calm down first. Recently you've been - how can I put this lightly - smothering.
You really think so?

Fields.MenuText: I do, but I also don't mind. You can smother me all you want.
And Henley, this war keeps me fully occupied.
Yes, and you won't leave me alone!

Fields.DialogueText: Captain! Your fresh talk is highly inappropriate. As you were saying?
But it's not like you're traveling anywhere. We're stuck with me on this ship, so you better learn to like it!
Is that really what you want, Captain?
Well…?
Why do you seem so reluctant to leave my side?
Shouldn't we stick together? Who knows what might happen out here?
*BOOM*
Just a joke, Captain. I get what you're saying, and it's hard to hear. But know that I'll never leave your side during battle.
Now that I can get behind.
@BATTLE
We'd be more prepared if we could stop distracting each other.
You find me distracting?
Oh, for-
You're a sad sight, Henley. I didn't expect to find you down here in the brig, pressed up against the steel bars.
Don't worry, Captain. I'm leaving you alone. You don't have to talk to me right now.
Oh, stop it. The yearbook again, huh? There's a face scribbled out... who's Shirley Averson? Ah, and the wrappers from several chocolate rations, I see.
Just go away, Captain. I don't want to smother you.

Fields.MenuText: You're being absurd. Come on, Henley. I just want to help.
Actually, I do have some deck duties to attend to.
Oh Henley, don't act like that. Remember what I said: you can smother me whenever you want.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, your help is appreciated but not needed!
Wait, don't go.
Captain, I know when you're just fooling around.
Listen, Henley, I think you may have some resentments from your college days.
What are you talking about, Captain? Are you some kind of head doctor now?
Who else could have affected you this way? Is Shirley someone you went to William and Mary with?
So what? Can you pass me that chocolate?
Here.
Well, are you going to explain to me how that's important?
The alarm! Sorry, Henley. No time for an explanation now.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Oh, how the tables turn... and yet don't.
Damn. Look sharp, everybody. Looks like there's even more of those things. Henley, prepare the turrets.
Whatever you say, Captain.
Henley, what's wrong?
Nothing, Captain. Nothing at all. Just as long as I imagine each of those Morganas are Shirley...
I know I'm going to regret it, but who-
My ex-friend! The winner of the big cookoff the year I graduated! The one who completely snubbed tasting my chili!

Fields.MenuText: I thought you couldn't cook?
Can this wait until later?
You're not worked up over that?

Fields.DialogueText: Well... not everything!
I wish it could too, Captain.
No! I mean, yes! Ugh... leave me alone, Captain.
All right, looks like I'm going to have to chase you down after the battle and figure this out.
You think you'll have time?
Call me a hypocrite, but this might just be a matter of national defense. Maybe even global defense.
@BATTLE
You sure know how to make a girl feel special. All right, I'll tell you all about it. Shirley took one look at my chili, and--
After. You're welcome to grab me by the lapels and sit me down to tell the tale.
... Yes, Captain!
All right, what's the problem?
I haven't seen you in a while because I don't want to smother you, Captain. And... that got me thinking about Shirley.
The girl from your year who snubbed your chili.
Oh, Captain, she wouldn't even look at it.
That's not what you said before.
... Yes it is.
I remember. You said she took one look at your chili and I cut you off before you could elaborate.
You're so thoughtful, Captain! I'm sorry I ever doubted you.

Fields.MenuText: I can't shake the feeling that you're hiding something.
Get to the point.
If you doubted me, you wouldn't have chosen me.

Fields.DialogueText: And so vigilant! I should be taking notes.
Right. I shouldn't be wasting your valuable time.
Chosen you... yeah, I think you're right.
So. Shirley. She snubbed your chili and went on to win.
That's why I've got to put my all into my cooking, Captain.
For revenge?
Aw, that's such an ugly word, Captain. College seems so long ago now, and the best way to deal with spite from back then is to get even better at what I like best.
Then count me in. This clearly means a lot to you, even if you haven't always expressed it in the best way.
I'm looking forward to it already. We're going to get a world-class meal out of you.
@BATTLE
You mean it, Captain? You'll stick with me through thick meat sauce and thin?
And... maybe a little revenge.
*ALARM*
One step at a time, I guess.
I'm a destroyer, Captain! I can't help it.
Is this okay?
That must be the third or fourth time you've asked. Yes, Henley, it's okay. I carved out some time for us to cook. Now, why don't you show me that chili you're famous for?
Oh! I, um... well, I hadn't really planned for that. Can't we just make pasta instead?

Fields.MenuText: You opened up to me only to demur on the chili?
We've had your pasta. I want to see something new from you.
If you really insist, but I thought this was about improvement.

Fields.DialogueText: Wouldn't you? Chili's a sore subject for me.
Oh, no... you didn't really like it, did you?
You can't improve on perfection, and my meat sauce is as close as it gets!
I hate to let you down, though. I don't want to give you a reason to leave me behind.
You're not letting me down.
Mmm… I guess you have been by my side the whole time.
Whatever happened between you and your friends, leave it in the past, Henley. I'm not going to pull a Shirley on you.
You think I can?
You've got new friends now, Henley.
I guess you're right.
I thought you'd be excited about that, Henley.
What if I want more than that?
Oh! There's the alarm. Sorry, Captain. Duty calls.
Hey! I'm the one who calls the shots here.
@BATTLE
Good work, Captain. I'm going to the galley now. Chili things. I just have to remember the recipe.
*ALARM*
There's so much more to discuss...
Henley? Are you ok?
Huh? Oh... yeah, Captain, I'm fine. Why?
You're standing in the galley, and there's no food around. I don't think I've ever seen this.
It does a seem a little odd, doesn't it? I guess I just got caught up in my thoughts.
I understand. I could only imagine the complex ideas you are burdened with.
Captain! Are you teasing me?
Well I can't have you looking like the neighborhood dog just died, Henley.
Aw, Captain, this means you really care about me, doesn't it?

Fields.MenuText: Of course I care about you. Don't be silly.
I care for every single man and woman aboard this ship, Henley.
A strong, beautiful, somewhat clumsy lady like you? How could I not care about you?

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks, Captain. Sorry if I can seem like a dark cloud sometimes.
I think I understand. Obligatory affection, Captain. Is that what you mean?
Oh, Captain, you really do know all the right things to say! And some of the less right ones, too.
Alright then, Captain, I'll spell it out loud for you. I was thinking about what you said. Maybe you're right.
That's a strange phrase… I'm not sure I've ever heard that language.
Oh, stop, Captain. I'm serious. I think you're right. Maybe I just need to leave this whole stupid Shirley Averson thing in the past.
Henley, I knew you had it in you.
Yeah! I mean, honestly, who knows how much longer I'll be out to sea anyway. Especially with the war, and the Morganas.
See, now you're starting to make some sense, Henley!
So if I start planning my revenge now, maybe by the time the war is over, I'll get another chance to see Shirley, and…
Wait, what? Hold on just a minute. I thought we'd ruled out revenge.
You did. I'm still working on it.
Henley, what am I going to do with you…
Well that's the alarm. So maybe you should order me to battle.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Memories?
Oh, Captain! I was just looking at this yearbook again.
You really miss your college days, don't you?
Don't you?

Fields.MenuText: That wasn't the question I asked.
A bit. It was kind of nice to think I knew everything.
Not really. I'm much more proud of what I'm doing out here.

Fields.DialogueText: But it's the one I'm more interested in.
Heh... in a way it still is.
Maybe that's what I should be focusing on.
Come on. This isn't about me.
Oh... Captain, you're going to think I'm awful.
Henley, for the last time, nothing you say could-
I never went to college!
What?
Don't act surprised. You never believed it in the first place. I'm an honorary graduate.
But... the yearbook...
It's a reissued '37. William and Mary ran my picture in it after I was awakened. I was commissioned that year, and my namesake went there, and...
What about Shirley?
Belle memories are weird, Captain. Wires get crossed now and again... old things I wasn't there for, new things I feel like I was.
And when the papers all talk about me as a genuine alum... well, it kind of feels nice, you know? That connection... the fame... It's easy to tell yourself something everyone else is telling you.
Except when you start making up rivalries.
That came later, Captain. After... after you started believing me, well, that became its own problem.
*ALARM*
Why don't we solve this one first? We'll talk about Shirley later. If that is indeed her name.
Aw, you're such a joker, Captain. That's what I lov- eep!
Pardon?
Nothing! It's go time!
@BATTLE
Command says it's only a matter of time now.
It's not really that bad out there, is it? We've faced some rough stuff before.
Command says it'll be a miracle if we survive. In their clinical, non-hyperbolic way, of course.
How encouraging of them. We're not a rust pile at the bottom of the ocean yet, Captain.
You've got a good attitude, Henley.
Captain? Do you ever think about the future?
I look forward to the day this war is over and I can have a cold beer and a hot coffee on dry land.
And a family? Do you ever think about finding a partner?

Fields.MenuText: Henley, slow down.
I'm committed to the safety of my nation; a commitment that keeps me from making any others.
The thought has crossed my mind. I guess it all depends on if I can find the right person.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh! Sorry, Captain. Sometimes I can put my nose where it doesn't belong. Especially if it's someone I find interesting.
Admirable words, Captain, but I wonder if your thoughts are the same.
Really, Captain? Well… What do you think this right person would look like?
Perhaps a talk for another time, Henley. There are a couple of duties yet to check off our list.
Right, of course. Silly me…
First order of business is…
*ALARM*
Deal with those Morganas?
Astute guess, Henley. Positions, everyone!
@BATTLE
I wouldn't be surprised if those ships were the first sign of our friends from the south. We don't have much time… Henley? Henley! Damn… there she goes again.
It's not hard to find you when you disappear, you know?
Captain, I wasn't trying to disappear. But you said we didn't have much time, and - well, I was starting to get hungry.
Spaghetti, huh?
It's the recipe you taught me, Captain. I think it's finally a dish I can make and be proud of.
Well you've certainly had plenty of practice. Now listen, I need you to round up every member of the crew who is able to leave their station.
Sounds exciting, Captain. Should I be worried?
You should have already been worried when I said it will be a miracle if we survive this.
Hmmm. I guess that just didn't do it. Do I have time to finish my pasta first?

Fields.MenuText: Make it quick.
I told you earlier that you were going to have some tasks to take care of. You'll have to eat it later, Henley.
Walk and eat at the same time, Henley. I've seen you do it before, and time is really of the essence here.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain. We both know I'm a much better fighter after I eat. Plus, I'll have no problem scarfing this down in seconds!
Of course. It's my fault. Sorry for being so immature, Captain.
I knew it would come in handy!
I have feeling this assault could be the fight of our lives. Gather the crew for a briefing and let me know when they are ready.
Aye-aye, Captain!
But first... maybe you could tell me what brought on that whole Shirley thing.
You're not going to let that go, are you?
What can I say? I learned from the best.
Heh. Well, once I realized how hard it was getting to keep up the charade... I thought I'd just point it in a different direction. And then we'd never, ever discuss it again.
Until you were betrayed by your love for chili.
I was really hungry, okay!? Ooh, if I'd just said she'd snubbed my spaghetti...
You don't... think less of me, do you?
I think differently of you.
Oh...
I think you put too much stock into what other people think of you. You shouldn't. You've brought us this far and kept us in some damn good food.
I don't need some storied history of your college days or rivalries to be proud of you. Even... somewhat frustratingly attracted.
... Captain. Here's what I know. We've got enough enemies coming for us without me having to make up any of my own.
I say we blast them from the face of the planet. And then we work on making friends. Maybe... more?
No more distractions. And I don't count you as a distraction. Quite the opposite.
@BATTLE
Captain? Is everything alright?
Fine. Why do you ask, Henley?
I just don't find you in the captain's quarters often, much less sitting on the bed like that.
Never mind that, Henley. Please tell me you assembled the crew like I asked?
Captain, when have I ever not done what you asked? They're waiting for you in the assembly hall.
You're a hell of a woman, Henley. I can always count on you.
Yep… We're all alone in here.
Perhaps it's time to brief the troops. Ready, Henley?
Actually Captain, if you'd like to pick up where we left off...
Yes?
Captain, sailing with you has been a whirlwind of adventure. You've put the wind back in my sails, the sizzle in my sauce. You've taught me how to cook, and…
Ah, look, Henley, don't mention it, really.
Helped me get over that stupid college thing I was distracting you with. Distracting me with.
Captain, I can't hide my true feelings any longer. You make me feel warm like a freshly baked cake.
I happen to really enjoy cake.
Oh, Captain! I've never felt so ready to fight.
Damn it… Look out the window, Henley.
Command wasn't kidding. Here come the Morganas.
Damn. They just keep coming.
We need to get to the crew.
There's not enough time. We'll just have to sound the alarm. It's our only hope.
Whatever happens… It's an honor to have called you Captain.
The affection is appreciated, Henley, but that talk needs to stop. We're going to make it through this even if we fire every torpedo on this ship.
They're moving within range, Captain.
All right, Henley. Let's get through this. Then I'll cook dinner for the both of us.
Right afterward? But... we're out of chocolate. What will we do for dessert?
We'll figure it out.
@BATTLE
... Is that all of them?
Maybe? ... Yes.
So let me tell you about my dessert idea. I think you might like it.
